capabilities.description: Use rich data collection and machine learning to correlate natural behavior with neural activity in animals and humans and decipher the “grammar” and subcomponents of bodily movement.

capabilities.name: Ex Vivo Human Brains
capabilities.description:
Utilize live human brains maintained ex vivo (“in a vat”) to study
  disease and drug responses more accurately.

capabilities.name: In Vitro Models of the Human Cortex
capabilities.description: Develop an in-dish model that mimics the structure and function of the human cortex, providing a controllable platform for studying cortical development, function, and disease.

capabilities.name: Mapping the Hypothalamus and Brainstem
capabilities.description: Systematically map how specific brain regions like the hypothalamus and brainstem (arguably the “steering subsystem” of the brain) drive innate behaviors and learning signals, and understand their role in obesity, chronic pain, fertility, inflammation, and other disorders.

capabilities.name: Data–Driven AI Models of Brain Systems
capabilities.description:
Use machine learning to construct functional digital emulations of human
  and primate brain systems. These models, built at varying levels of fidelity,
  support automated interpretability and data-driven discovery.

capabilities.name: Embodied Testbeds for Neuro–Cognitive Models
capabilities.description: Develop virtual models (e.g., a virtual fly, rodent) to simulate neuro–cognitive processes in a controlled, embodied environment.

capabilities.name: Digital Replicas of the Whole Brain of a Model Organism
capabilities.description: Construct a digital replica of a model organism’s brain (e.g., C. elegans) that accurately recapitulates neuronal activity and behavior.

capabilities.name:
Micro- to Nano-Scale Minimally Invasive
  BCI Transducers
capabilities.description:
Harmless nanoscale transducers to record or modulate brain activity that
  can be delivered minimally invasively.

capabilities.name: Less Invasive Access to the Brain Through Very Tiny Skull Holes
capabilities.description: Access brain fluids through much tinier holes than currently possible to facilitate less invasive delivery of drugs or devices to intracranial or intraventricular spaces.

capabilities.name: Noninvasive Blood–Based Measurement of Brain Biomarkers
capabilities.description:
Use peripheral sampling methods to indirectly monitor brain molecular
  biomarkers. One approach involves using ultrasound to transiently open the
  blood–brain barrier, releasing engineered protein markers into the
  bloodstream for detection.

capabilities.name: Fully Noninvasive Neural Read–Write Technologies
capabilities.description:
Use noninvasive modalities—such as ambient field magnetoencephalography
  (MEG) with quantum gradiometers, sono–magnetic tomography, optical
  interference methods, and ultrasound modulated optical tomography—to record
  and modulate brain activity without surgery.

capabilities.name:
Minimally Invasive Ultrasound–Based Whole
  Brain Computer Interface
capabilities.description:
Develop a minimally invasive ultrasound-based platform that can interface
  programmably with the whole human brain. This approach leverages ultrasound’s
  ability to penetrate deep tissues, offering scalable imaging and modulation
  with minimal invasiveness.

capabilities.name: Faster Electron Microscopy for Connectomics
capabilities.description: Develop new physical detection methods for electron microscopy that improves scalability of visualization of brain circuitry.

capabilities.name: Rapid High–Resolution Neural Circuit Visualization
capabilities.description:
Combine advanced imaging
  methods—such as synchrotron X–ray microscopy and expansion microscopy—to
  rapidly and scalably image neural circuits in both small and large brain
  regions. This method promises high spatial resolution with faster throughput.

capabilities.name: Scalable, Anatomically and Molecularly Dense Brain Mapping Technology
capabilities.description: Develop a scalable technology that can map the brain’s wiring at the single–cell level and link molecular and circuit properties.
